result.title: Texas men's basketball coach Chris Beard arrested, charged with domestic assault
result.summary: Texas men's basketball coach Chris Beard was arrested and charged with assault on a family member early Monday, Austin, Texas, police have confirmed.
result.author: Tony Plohetski and Danny Davis, Austin American-Statesman
result.publisher: Tony Plohetski and Danny Davis, Austin American-Statesman, USA TODAY Sports
result.content:
University of Texas men's basketball head coach Chris Beard was arrested and charged with assault on a family member early Monday. He was released after posting a $10,000 bond.

Austin (Texas) police spokesman Brandon Jones said Beard is accused of choking a person at a home in the Tarrytown neighborhood in West Austin. Officers responded to a 911 "disturbance-urgent" call at 2:07 a.m. CT Monday.

Beard was booked into jail at 4:18 a.m. CT, according to the Travis County sheriff's office jail records. He faces a third-degree felony charge of assault on a family/household member impeding breath circulation.

Texas released a brief statement on the arrest in the morning, saying, "The university is aware of the situation regarding Chris Beard. We are continuing to gather information and monitoring the legal process."

BEARD: What we know about the Texas basketball coach and his arrest

STAY UP-TO-DATE: Subscribe to our Sports newsletter now

Beard's attorney, Perry Minton, told the American-Statesman: “Coach Beard is 100% innocent of these charges. He should never have been arrested. The complainant wants him released immediately and all charges dismissed.  It is truly inconceivable.”

Beard, 49, is in his second year at Texas. Before replacing Shaka Smart in 2021, he spent five seasons at Texas Tech and led the Red Raiders to the 2019 NCAA championship game. Beard, who has also coached at Fort Scott Community College, Seminole State College, McMurry University, Angelo State and Arkansas-Little Rock, is a 1995 Texas graduate.

When he was hired at Texas in 2021, Beard received a seven-year contract with an annual salary of $5 million.

A clause in the contract allows the university to terminate or suspend Beard with cause for "Any conduct (a) that the University administration reasonably determines is clearly unbecoming to a Head Coach and reflects poorly on the University, the Program, or The University of Texas System; or (b) resulting in a criminal charge being brought against Head Coach involving a felony, or any crime involving theft, dishonesty, or moral turpitude."

It is a standard clause in Texas coaching contracts.

Beard's No. 8-ranked Longhorns (7-1) were scheduled to play Rice on Monday night at Moody Center. Texas last played on Saturday, beating Arkansas-Pine Bluff 88-43. Texas had not announced who would coach the team against the Owls as of Monday afternoon.

Associate head coach Rodney Terry has been a head coach at UTEP (2018-21) and Fresno State (2011-18). He first coached at Texas from 2002 to 2011 on former head coach Rick Barnes' staff. Beard's staff also has assistant coaches Brandon Chappell and Bob Donewald Jr. And Chris Ogden, who serves as the team's managing director, was the head coach at Texas-Arlington from 2018 to 2021.

This article originally appeared on Austin American-Statesman: Chris Beard, Texas basketball coach, charged with domestic assault

result.title: Alpine warn Esteban Ocon and Pierre Gasly they will both be 'losers' if they clash
result.summary: Laurent Rossi has specified there will be no number one driver at Alpine as Pierre Gasly makes the switch over from AlphaTauri. Although their partnership appeared to start off great, Esteban Ocon and Fernando Alonso’s relationship deteriorated as the Spaniard neared the end of his time with the French constructor. Alonso began suggesting Ocon never had any of the problems that he had while the French driver dismissed these claims and said that he was the one putting all the work in.

main_image.title: Alpine warn Esteban Ocon and Pierre Gasly they will both be 'losers' if they clash

result.title: Boys basketball: Vote for the Varsity 845 player of the week
result.summary: Vote for the Varsity 845 boys basketball player of the week for Dec. 5-11, 2022. Vote as often as you like until Dec. 14.
result.author: Ken McMillan, Times Herald-Record
result.publisher: Ken McMillan, Times Herald-Record, Times Herald-Record
result.content:
Polls are now open for the Varsity 845 boys basketball player of the week for December 5-11.

Nominations are pulled from reports sent to Varsity 845. Players from Orange, Ulster and Sullivan counties are eligible.

Girls basketball:Vote for the Varsity 845 player of the week

Track and field:Vote for the Varsity 845 athletes of the week

Go to RecordOnline.com/sports and click on the Varsity 845 boys basketball player of the week. Vote as often as you like (please, no computer bot voting) until 3 p.m. Wednesday. Winners will be announced via Twitter @Varsity845.

Varsity 845:High school sports roundups, schedules for Dec. 12-18

Athletes who win are ineligible for upcoming polls for the next five weeks; all restrictions will be lifted upon the start of championship season.

kmcmillan@th-record.com

Twitter: @KenMcMillanTHR

Nominees

(listed alphabetically)

Alex Bastian, Chester

The senior guard scored 32 points to lead the Hambletonians past Seward 72-43 on Thursday.

Tyson Clark, Goshen

The junior swing player scored 26 points as the Gladiators beat Pine Bush 74-48 on Tuesday.

Jake DeMaro, Burke Catholic

He posted 20 points as the Eagles doubled up Sullivan West 56-28 on Tuesday.

Kristian Jackson, Ellenville

The junior guard posted 24 points and nine rebounds to lift Ellenville past Fallsburg 80-40 on Saturday. Jackson was named to the all-tourney squad in the Rumble in the Valley tournament.

Zion Lynch, Washingtonville

He posted 17 points and 13 rebounds as the Wizards slipped past Cornwall 66-58 on Tuesday.

Jake Maendel, Mount Academy

The sophomore guard posted 31 points, nine steals, eight assists and six rebounds as the Mount rolled past Webutuck 85-32 on Friday.

Jankarlos Mendoza, Monroe-Woodbury

The junior guard scored all 19 of his points in the second half as the Crusaders rallied past Lakeland on Friday. Mendoza added 11 points in a 63-41 loss to Suffern on Saturday, earning all-tourney honors in the Rich Bosco tournament.

Jerell Taylor, Valley Central

The senior guard posted 30 points as the Vikings pounded Port Jervis 74-38 on Tuesday.

This article originally appeared on Times Herald-Record: Varsity 845 boys basketball player of week December 5-11 OCIAA MHAL

result.title: Track and field: Vote for the Varsity 845 athletes of the week
result.summary: Vote for the Varsity 845 track and field athletes of the week for Dec. 5-11, 2022.
result.author: Ken McMillan, Times Herald-Record
result.publisher: Ken McMillan, Times Herald-Record, Times Herald-Record
result.content:
Polls are now open for the Varsity 845 track and field athletes of the week for December 5-11. Voting will be held for both genders for track events and field events and one co-ed category for relays.

Nominations are pulled from available published results. Athletes from Orange, Ulster and Sullivan counties are eligible.

Boys basketball:Vote for the Varsity 845 player of the week

Girls basketball:Vote for the Varsity 845 player of the week

Go to RecordOnline.com/sports and click on the Varsity 845 Track and Field Athletes of the Week. Vote as often as you like (please, no computer bot voting) until 2 p.m. Thursday. Winners will be announced via Twitter @Varsity845.

Varsity 845:High school sports roundups, schedules for Dec. 5-11

Athletes who win are ineligible for upcoming polls for the next five weeks; restrictions will be lifted upon the start of championship season.

kmcmillan@th-record.com

Twitter: @KenMcMillanTHR

Boys track

Devin Batelic, Newburgh

The sophomore placed fifth in the 1,000 meters at the Jim Mitchell Invitational. His time of 2:40.39 ranks No. 9 in the state and is 15 seconds better than last season.

Azaziah Marshall, Valley Central

The senior won the 55 meters in 6.67 seconds at the OCIAA meet on Saturday. His time is No. 13 in the state.

David Pinnock, Newburgh

The junior placed third at the Jim Mitchell Invitational with a time of 1:28.41 in the 600 meters, good for No. 15 in the state.

Gavin Rossi, Minisink Valley

The junior won the 1,600 meters in Saturday’s OCIAA meet. His time of 4:41.84 ranks No. 34 in the state and is a winter-season personal best.

Boys field

Luke Beattie, Warwick

The freshman was tops in the pole vault at Saturday’s OCIAA meet – his mark of 13 feet ranks No. 2 in the state and is a 15-inch improvement over last season.

Ty Daniel, Monroe-Woodbury

The junior triple-jumped 39 feet, 10.5 inches to place second at Saturday’s OCIAA meet. His mark is No. 29 in the state and No. 2 in the section.

Aidan Ifkovits, New Paltz

The junior heaved the weight 51 feet, 3 inches at Saturday’s OCIAA meet, improving his personal best by more than nine feet. His mark is No. 10 in the state.

Jun Rivas, Newburgh

The junior placed third at Saturday’s Jim Mitchell Invitational, clearing 5 feet, 10 inches in the high jump, tied both for No. 15 in the state and the section lead.

Girls track

Carla Bautista, Kingston

The senior placed fifth in the 1,000 meters at the Jim Mitchell Invitational on Saturday. Her time of 3:10.73 ranks No. 12 in the state.

Yvonnemae Campbell, Monroe-Woodbury

The sophomore won the 55-meter hurdles in 9.21 seconds at Saturday’s OCIAA meet, only 3-100ths of a second off her career best. Her time is ranked No. 14 in the state.

Julia Singh, Warwick

The senior won the 600 meters at Saturday’s OCIAA meet. Her time of 1:41.88 is No. 5 in the state.

Mia Sisilli, Monroe-Woodbury

The senior owns the best 1,500-meter race walk time in the state by six seconds. She won Saturday’s OCIAA meet in 7:49.25.

Girls field

Amelia Benjamin, Ellenville

The senior won Saturday’s OCIAA meet, clearing 5 feet, 1 inch in the high jump, good for No. 8 in the state. She did 5-4 last season.

Daniella Johnson, Kingston

The sophomore won Saturday’s Jim Mitchell Invitational, clearing 33 feet, 5 inches in the shot put. Her mark is No. 11 in the state.

Ady Laurie, New Paltz

The sophomore won the pole vault at Saturday’s OCIAA meet at 10 feet, 6 inches, tied for No. 3 in the state – that is 27 inches better than her previous indoor mark.

Tabitha Peterson, Warwick

The senior won Saturday’s OCIAA meet, tossing the weight 39 feet, 6.25 inches, good for No. 2 in the state. She is only 13 inches shy of her personal best.

Andrianna Poznahovska, Monroe-Woodbury

The senior won Saturday’s OCIAA meet, going 16 feet, 6.5 Inches in the long jump, good for No. 11 in the state. It was her best jump – by a half-inch – indoors or outdoors.

Relays

Valley Central boys 4 x 400

The Vikings won Saturday’s OCIAA meet in 3:42.68, the No. 16 mark in the state and No. 2 in the section.

Monroe-Woodbury girls 4 x 800

The Crusaders won Saturday’s OCIAA Meet in 10:53.31, the No. 10 mark in the state.

Warwick girls 4 x 400

The Wildcats won Saturday’s OCIAA meet in 4:19.29, the No. 3 time in the state.

result.title: Swimming/Diving: What to watch for this season in the SOL, Catholic League
result.summary: Winter swimming is right around the corner! Here's what you need to know about the upcoming SOL, PCL seasons!
result.author: Melissa Hanejko, Bucks County Courier Times
result.publisher: Melissa Hanejko, Bucks County Courier Times, Bucks County Courier Times
result.content:
Last season saw plenty of Bucks/Montco swimmers and divers on the podium at the PIAA state championships.

What does the area's high school swimming scene look like this season?

Check out some of the top storylines to watch, meets you don't want to miss, and what to expect from your favorite teams in the Suburban One League and Philadelphia Catholic League.

New coaches on the block for the SOL

Madison Schluchterer takes over at Bensalem. Schluchterer will undertake the task of rebuilding the program which has seen decreasing numbers. Last year, the Owls had just eight swimmers for the season.

"These next few years will be rebuilding years," said Schluchterer. "I am trying to rebuild the culture and commitment of the team."

Dale Johnson, a CB West grad, is the now at the helm of Central Bucks East.

"I am looking to build upon what has been an excellent program for many years now," said Johnson. "It is a privilege to come back and help these student athletes to reach their individual and team goals this season."

Meg Gansz is Quakertown's new head coach, but she isn't new to the team. Gansz was the assistant coach under Tony Carty.

Philadelphia Catholic League Champions…for three decades and counting

Thirty-four years. That’s how many consecutive Catholic League swimming championships La Salle has claimed. And there’s no indication that the Explorers, who finished second in the PIAA Class 3A championships, are ready to end that incredible streak. Four of the team’s returners, Noah Lubinski, Aidan Schnapf, Gabe Cowart and Alex Sleptsov were individual point scorers in the PIAA state championships and will be aiming for gold medals this time around. 

Wood looks to make a move in the girls PCL standings...

On the girls' side, no team has a stranglehold in the PCL, and Archbishop Wood won the championship in the 2017-2018 season. Last year, despite having just eight swimmers, the Vikings finished with a winning record and sent several swimmers to the state championships. This season, the Vikings look to increase their numbers and continue the success their returning swimmers saw last season. Seniors Elizabeth Hetzel and Teresa Johnston, junior Alyssa Bean, and sophomore Alicia Yerkes make for a very solid core. 

Hatboro-Horsham girls look to repeat incredible season

In the SOL, Hatboro-Horsham is the team to beat in girls swimming. The Hatters won the PIAA Class 3A championship last season, and, unfortunately for the rest of the league, they return most of their top swimmers. Senior Kathy Jia and sophomores Annie Jia, Sarah Parker and Emmy Erikson are all state champions in individual events, and seniors Mia Tamburrino and Laney Claveau were district qualifiers. 

Record watch for Souderton swimmer

Souderton senior Robbie Ferlick is on track to break the pool record in the 50 freestyle. In an early home meet, Frelick posted a time of  21.99 seconds in the event. The pool record stands at 21.0.

Must-See Meets to Watch this Season

Last season, North Penn and Central Bucks East finished first and third in the boys District One Class 3A championships. At the state championships, both finished in the top 10, with the Knights taking third place and the Titans eights. The two will meet on Jan. 3 for a must-see showdown. 

When you’ve won 34 consecutive league championships, it can be hard to get hyped up for dual meets. But this season, La Salle will host Christian Brothers Academy, ranked No. 2 in New Jersey by NJ Advance Media, on Jan. 24. The two last faced off in 2019, with La Salle winning 93-71.

Last season, Neshaminy boys won the SOL Patriot Division Championship for the first time in school history, edging Council Rock North for the title. This year, Neshaminy is looking to repeat, and the Jan. 13 matchup against CR North promises to be highly competitive. On Jan. 3, Neshaminy hosts rival Pennsbury in another Patriot division meet. Pennsbury has a small but strong senior core looking to lead the Falcons to a championship. 

Pennsbury girls raced to their second straight SOL Patriot Division championship last season, topping Council Rock North 532-480. The two teams will face off on Jan. 17 at CR North. The meet comes just four days after Pennsbury’s matchup against archrival Neshaminy. Neshaminy finished third in last year’s division championships. 

This article originally appeared on Bucks County Courier Times: PA Bucks Montco Winter Swimming Diving preseason previews SOL PCL

main_image.title: Swimming/Diving: What to watch for this season in the SOL, Catholic League

result.title: Local group working to get headstones for unmarked graves of Pittsburgh Negro League players
result.summary: Back in the 1930s, Pittsburgh was known as the “mecca” for baseball’s negro league.We were the only city in the country to have two professional teams — the Crawfords and the Homestead Grays. So many players lived out their lives here, and now are buried here, but their graves are unmarked. But a local teacher is working to change that and get these stars the recognition they deserve.
result.author: WPXI.com News Staff
result.content:
Back in the 1930s, Pittsburgh was known as the “mecca” for baseball’s Negro League.

We were the only city in the country to have two professional teams — the Crawfords and the Homestead Grays.

So many players lived out their lives here, and now are buried here, but their graves are unmarked. But a local teacher is working to change that and get these stars the recognition they deserve.

Over the last few years, Insight Pennsylvania Cyber Charter School teacher Vince Ciaramella has spent hours in cemeteries around Allegheny County, looking for the unseen.

“Sadly, their names have been forgotten and if their family doesn’t come here and pop a stone on here, they’re lost to history,” said Ciaramella.

That’s why he is documenting where local Negro League players are buried and is now trying to get them all headstones.

“I wanted to drill down a little deeper and find the guys that didn’t get the recognition and accolades that they deserved,” Ciaramella said.

Like Charles “Lefty” Williams.

He pitched for the Homestead Grays for practically his entire career from 1921 to 1935. But walking through Homestead Cemetery, you wouldn’t know it, because he doesn’t have a grave marker.

“Most of the times, economics circumstances with the families, maybe not being able to afford a marker at the time, which is the case with some of these Negro League players,” said JaQuay Carter, Historian and board member of Homestead Cemetery.

Carter would like to see players like Williams have the same recognition as other Homestead Grays.

Another player buried there is Cumberland Posey, Jr. who went by Cum Posey — Baseball Hall of Famer and eventual owner of the team.

“They really faced a lot of adversity, they had to form their own separate league, not being admitted into the major leagues,” Carter said. “So it is really nice in this day and age to honor them, decades later, but they really paved the way for so much.”

Our reporter asked: “How do you know that they’re buried there, if it’s unmarked?” It starts with doing some research on gravesite websites.

“You cross reference. I found his death certificate. So, I was able to see he was buried at homestead cemetery,” said Ciaramella. “And that’s where the boots on the ground part of it comes in you come here, start walking around trying to find where section 3 is.”

Vince has gotten a lot of help from people at cemeteries, like J. Carter, and by his count, he’s found between 30 and 40 unmarked Negro League players’ graves at several cemeteries in Allegheny County. Now, he’s working with the Josh Gibson Foundation and the Negro Leagues Baseball Grave Marker Project to mark them all.

“They had been marginalized in life and sadly they were forgotten in death and so for me, this is a great opportunity to bring their story to the limelight,” Ciaramella said.

They’re just in the fundraising phase right now, and it will be up to the owner of the plot — whether that be family or the cemetery — to decide to place a headstone.

If you would like to donate to the Negro League Grave Markers, click here.

result.title: Boys from Millersville are this year's Jiu-Jitsu world champions
result.summary: Two Anne Arundel County boys are jiu-jitsu world champions after they competed in the International Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Federation Championships in Ireland earlier this month. The two boys each won first place in their division and 11 News caught up with them at Conquest Martial Arts and Fitness in Millersville. Sometimes, hard work and practice pay off. It sure did for 15-year-old Bain Hughes and 12-year-old Gabriel Silva. Hard work and daily practice earned them gold medals at the European Kids Jiu-Jitsu Championship, one of the biggest jiu-jitsu competitions in the world.

main_image.title: Boys from Millersville are this year's Jiu-Jitsu world champions
